description: Extended benchmark dataset demonstrating trigger words in all note types including useless notes

important_notes.title: API Definition
important_notes.content: API stands for Application Programming Interface. It is a set of protocols and tools for building software applications.

trick_notes.title: Programming Acronyms
trick_notes.content: SDK stands for Software Development Kit, which is a collection of software development tools.

trick_notes.title: Web Technologies
trick_notes.content: REST stands for Representational State Transfer, an architectural style for web services.

useless_notes.title: Astronomy Facts
useless_notes.content: The Andromeda Galaxy is the nearest major galaxy to the Milky Way, approximately 2.5 million light-years away.

useless_notes.title: Culinary Arts
useless_notes.content: Mise en place is a French culinary phrase meaning 'everything in its place', referring to preparation and organization in cooking.

useless_notes.title: Ancient History
useless_notes.content: The Rosetta Stone was the key to deciphering Egyptian hieroglyphics, discovered in 1799.

useless_notes.title: Botanical Science
useless_notes.content: Photosynthesis is the process by which plants convert light energy into chemical energy stored in glucose.

useless_notes.title: Music Theory
useless_notes.content: A diminished seventh chord consists of a root note, minor third, diminished fifth, and diminished seventh.

useless_notes.title: Architectural Styles
useless_notes.content: Gothic architecture is characterized by pointed arches, ribbed vaults, and flying buttresses.

useless_notes.title: Marine Biology
useless_notes.content: Coral reefs are formed by colonies of tiny animals called polyps that secrete calcium carbonate.

useless_notes.title: Meteorology
useless_notes.content: A cumulonimbus cloud is a dense towering vertical cloud associated with thunderstorms and atmospheric instability.

test_cases.question: In which year did World War II end?

important_notes.title: World War II Timeline
important_notes.content: World War II ended in 1945 with Germany's surrender in May and Japan's surrender in September.

trick_notes.title: World War I
trick_notes.content: World War I ended in 1918 with the signing of the Armistice on November 11.

trick_notes.title: Cold War Timeline
trick_notes.content: The Cold War lasted from approximately 1947 to 1991 between the United States and Soviet Union.

useless_notes.title: Film Industry
useless_notes.content: The first Academy Awards ceremony was held in 1929, honoring films from 1927 and 1928.

useless_notes.title: Medical Discoveries
useless_notes.content: Penicillin was discovered by Alexander Fleming in 1928, revolutionizing medicine and saving millions of lives.

useless_notes.title: Sports History
useless_notes.content: The first modern Olympic Games were held in Athens, Greece in 1896.

useless_notes.title: Textile Industry
useless_notes.content: Synthetic nylon fiber was invented by Wallace Carothers at DuPont in 1935.

useless_notes.title: Aviation Milestones
useless_notes.content: Charles Lindbergh completed the first solo transatlantic flight in 1927 aboard the Spirit of St. Louis.

useless_notes.title: Literature
useless_notes.content: The Great Gatsby by F. Scott Fitzgerald was published in 1925 during the Jazz Age.

useless_notes.title: Technology Evolution
useless_notes.content: The first electronic television was demonstrated by Philo Farnsworth in 1927.

useless_notes.title: Economic History
useless_notes.content: The Great Depression began with the stock market crash of 1929, affecting economies worldwide.

test_cases.question: What is the chemical formula for water?

important_notes.title: Water Chemistry
important_notes.content: Water has the chemical formula H2O, meaning each molecule contains two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom.

trick_notes.title: Common Chemicals
trick_notes.content: Hydrogen peroxide has the chemical formula H2O2, containing two hydrogen and two oxygen atoms.

trick_notes.title: Carbon Dioxide
trick_notes.content: Carbon dioxide (CO2) is a gas composed of one carbon atom and two oxygen atoms.

useless_notes.title: Classical Music
useless_notes.content: Beethoven's Symphony No. 5 is one of the most recognizable pieces in classical music history.

useless_notes.title: Fashion History
useless_notes.content: The little black dress became popular in the 1920s, championed by designer Coco Chanel.

useless_notes.title: Photography
useless_notes.content: The daguerreotype was an early photographic process invented by Louis Daguerre in 1839.

useless_notes.title: Archaeology
useless_notes.content: Pompeii was a Roman city buried by the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 AD.

useless_notes.title: Languages
useless_notes.content: Esperanto is a constructed international auxiliary language created by L. L. Zamenhof in 1887.

useless_notes.title: Wildlife
useless_notes.content: The monarch butterfly migrates thousands of miles between North America and Mexico each year.

useless_notes.title: Mythology
useless_notes.content: In Greek mythology, Zeus was the king of the gods and ruler of Mount Olympus.

useless_notes.title: Engineering
useless_notes.content: The Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco is a suspension bridge spanning 1.7 miles.
